SystemOutput2: The doctor is speaking with a patient who just turned 55 and identifies as an African American. The doctor is discussing the patient's past medical history, specifically mentioning an MRI that revealed a right contrast temporal mass. The patient previously had seizures and the doctor is concerned that the mass could be a high grade glioma, and further testing will be required.
Patient reports history of stroke and sleep apnea in family medical history.
Patient denies any muscle, joint, or back pain, stiffness, or weakness.
The patient does not have any diabetes, blood or heart issues in their family.
The patient's father died of thoracic aortic aneurysm at age 71, and her mother died of a stroke at around age 81.
Medical and social history have not changed since the last appointment.
77 year old patient sedated with Ativan due to shortness of breath. Xray shows free air under right diaphragm.

The patient does not have any significant health issues, but has a family history of DVT, diabetes, bone cancer, leukemia, and colon cancer. Some family members have been diagnosed with these conditions while others have a genetic predisposition for them.
Patient is retired and enjoys travelling with his wife. He drinks socially but does not smoke or use any drugs.
No known medication allergies.
African American woman, 79 years old, 5'3" and 197 lbs, with type 2 diabetes since 1983 and no known allergies to medication.

The patient had received his BCG vaccine in the Philippines before starting elementary school, and his immunization records were already submitted. The patient had been experiencing stomach discomfort for a few days, but had no history of liver problems, gallbladder stones, fever, chills, or ulcers. The patient had also undergone a physical and blood test previously, and results indicated normal health.
The doctor inquires about the patient's living situation and support system, then discusses the patient's smoking habit and encourages them to quit.

The doctor asked about the patient's recent health status, anxiety management, and blood pressure. The patient said they started going to therapy and will see a psychiatrist next week for anxiety management. They also mentioned no problems with their blood pressure since taking medication.
Discussion about the patient's liver health including questions about alcohol, Tylenol use, and smoking.
The doctor asks the patient a series of questions regarding headaches, breathlessness, skin problems, chest pain and other issues, but the patient reports not having any of these symptoms.
The doctor asks the patient about the color of their skin and any swelling in their body, but the patient denies having noticed any changes in their skin color or any swelling in their body.
The patient has not had any health problems or surgeries in the past.

The patient complains of fatigue, and the doctor explains that multiple underlying conditions such as hypertension, high cholesterol, and osteoarthritis can cause it. The doctor advises the patient to prioritize their health.

This is a follow-up appointment with a female patient who has had issues with acne and has been experiencing a rash for the last two months. The doctor examines the rash and diagnoses it as folliculitis, which may be related to the patient's acne flaring up. The doctor reviews the patient's previous medication and suggests that she continue with it and avoid stopping it. The patient has been receiving photofacials at Healing Waters, which has been helpful, but is interested in other procedures or skincare products to help her look younger.

The patient is experiencing leg swelling and numbness, and is unable to move around due to their weight and shortness of breath from COPD. They are experiencing constant pain and taking OxyContin. They have sores on their legs that are oozing. The doctor examines the sores.

The patient has been experiencing a new gnawing chest pain for the past few nights, lasting only a few seconds, and rated as a five or six out of ten. The patient has not taken any pain relief medication, and has not experienced any other symptoms such as shortness of breath or leg swelling.
Patient had been happily married for 45 years and lived in their dream house by the bay. They quit smoking in 1997 but occasionally enjoy a glass of wine or beer.

The guest clinician, Mary, asks the patient about their medical and family history, as well as any pre-existing medical issues. The patient mentions they have sinus and had a stroke two years ago. They also indicate they do not smoke, drink, or have any allergies. Mary informs the patient that Doctor Smith will be checking them soon.

The doctor warns the patient to avoid foods with high salt levels such as chips, junk food, and pickles due to the harmful effects on the patient's current condition. The patient agrees to cut down on salty foods and follow a low-salt diet.
The patient's family medical history includes arthritis in the patient's grandmother and psoriasis in the patient's father. The patient did not have arthritis as a child.

This is a follow-up appointment for a 68-year-old male with a history of ischemic cardiac disease. The patient had a treadmill test in February 2004, and the doctor has the results which showed wall scarring but normal blood flow from the heart. The doctor asks about any symptoms, but the patient reports not having any chest pain, palpitations, difficulty sleeping, or shortness of breath while lying flat.
The patient is experiencing nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and fever.
The patient mentioned by Doctor Pai was discharged and went home, which the other doctor found great news.
Prostate cancer with metastasis.
The doctor is inquiring about any major medical conditions that run in the patient's family. The patient mentions that their father has arthritis in both hips.

The patient, a 55-year-old, visits Dr. Jones with a complaint of weakness in his right leg, tingling and numbness for six months. The symptoms occurred after he tried to reach for something from a cabinet. The patient experienced mild numbness and tingling but had no pain in the right leg. He also had mild back pain for many years â€“ no changes. However, he experienced calf cramps for a year, which stopped two months before the doctor's visit. He did not have similar symptoms in the left leg, nor did he have bowel or bladder incontinence or radicular pain. The patient underwent a CT scan and nerve conductivity studies, but no MRI due to his ear implants. The patient's CK levels increased after taking Lipitor for 15 months, and after discontinuing it, they returned to about the 500's. He has recently started taking Zetia but has not experienced any weakness or pain after taking it.
1. Small amount of liquid ingested. 2. Not likely to be toxic. 3. Patient behaving as though not ingested.
The patient reports not smoking cigarettes or drinking alcohol. The doctor acknowledges this and the conversation ends.
The patient reports that their sugar levels are under control, but they have hepatitis C and HIV in addition to other medical conditions.
The patient is allergic to Bactrim and experiences nausea and vomiting. They also believe they are allergic to adhesive tape and get a skin rash when they use it.

The doctor is speaking to a 56-year-old female patient who got injured and is experiencing pain in her foot. She doesn't remember how the injury occurred but says it happened on November 26, 2007. She has no other injuries besides the one in her foot.
Patient has been smoking around one pack per day for fifteen years. The patient is also an opioid addict and consumes alcohol regularly. The patient expresses a need for help.

The patient is a white female with knee pain, even after receiving three Synvisc injections. The most recent injection was given five days ago and provided 35-40% relief, but she still experiences pinching pain and cannot fully bend or straighten the knee. She rates her pain as a 10 out of 10 and uses ice, heat, Tylenol with codeine, and ibuprofen, but these treatments provide minimal relief.
No changes in the previous medical and social history. Non-smoker, non-drinker, no drug use, no past surgeries or medical conditions.

The doctor informed the patient that their intestine infection, specifically C Diff colitis, has been resolved according to Doctor X. The patient saw this doctor two weeks prior. The doctor also reminds the patient about their hypertension and high cholesterol. The patient thanks the doctor.
Patient complains of congestion and a possible fever. Doctor offers to provide assistance.

The patient is a 68-year-old who has been experiencing a bad cough with green and grey sputum for three days. The patient visited the Emergency Department due to concern regarding the sputum. The cough has not caused any shortness of breath, fever, or chills.
Good news as there are no signs of any abdominal issues.
The patient has health conditions including obesity, high blood pressure, previous knee fracture with surgery, and history of blood clots.
The patient was placed on a nasogastric tube for decompression, which has resulted in the patient feeling a bit better.
Patient has congestion for a few years due to enlarged adenoids, saw an ENT a year ago, but currently has no plans to follow up. Also has an ingrown toenail that seems to be improving on its own.
Two-month-old baby girl with congestion and fever. Doctor asks about other symptoms, milk intake, and diaper changes.
Patient complains of headache. Possible stress-related. Denied smoking.

A 77-year-old white female has a medical history of lumbar scoliosis post laminectomy syndrome, lumbar spinal stenosis and symptomatic right L2 radiculopathy. She had surgery for spinal stenosis and received injections into her lower back from Doctor XYZ. After her last injection in March 2005, she had hip injections in April 2005. X-rays show marked degenerative changes since August 2004 when she saw Doctor XYZ for imaging on her right hip. She is still experiencing pain even though she takes the generic form of Ultracet. She also mentioned that walking aggravates the pain. She is scheduled for an appointment with an orthopedist.

The patient has hurt his left wrist again while lifting things out of his car trunk. He has had previous injuries to his wrist that were sore and had chronic scapholunate problems with ligament damage. The recent injury has made his pain worse and is now mostly felt in the ulnar side of his wrist. The doctor will evaluate and treat accordingly.
Patient denies current medications.
No known drug allergies.
He is a widower and lives alone. Denies tobacco, alcohol, and illegal drug use. He is retired and physically active.

MEDICAL CHECK-UP: Doctor checks patient's blood sugar readings and cholesterol levels. Patient has not experienced any significant symptoms except for high cholesterol, which the doctor recommends monitoring and continuing with medication. Patient's sinus symptoms have improved since taking medication. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for additional bloodwork in a few weeks.
Stomach problems- diarrhea for several weeks, 5-6 times/day.
The patient denies any problems with their eyesight, including blurred or double vision, partial loss of vision, or blind spots. The patient confirms they have no loss of vision.
Patient experiencing sudden disorientation and memory loss, potentially requiring cognitive tests by a specialist.

Patient occasionally experiences overactive bladder. No urinary pain or other symptoms. No abdominal pain, excessive thirst or eating, constipation, diarrhea, heartburn, chest pain or tightness, shortness of breath, headaches, or fever. Doctor orders ultrasound of kidneys and urine test.
Family history of asthma, no other major medical conditions mentioned.
1. EKG is normal with a leftward axis variation. 2. Blood tests results are normal with negative cardiac enzymes.
The patient is not taking any medication except Amoxil and Aldex, which were started on Monday.

The guest clinician asks the age of the patient and if they determined what was obstructing her airways. The doctor explains that the patient is seventeen and had a two millimeter fishbone lodged in her throat, requiring immediate intubation and transfer to the operating room.

The patient has high lipid levels, high blood pressure and a possibility for a metabolic syndrome. The patient has been following a meal plan given by the doctor but still gained weight. The patient is also doing gardening and yard work for physical activity. The patient has gone back to the old South Beach Diet and lost some weight but knows it's not healthy. The doctor appreciates the patient's honesty and suggests setting a plan for a low-fat diet.

The patient is feeling short of breath for the past three days when exerting themselves, with no leg or chest pain. The doctor suggests getting a chest CT scan and confirms that the patient does not have asthma. The patient's pulse ox is high, so they don't need oxygen at this time.
Chemotherapy prescribed, patient feeling better.

The doctor asks the patient about their previous medical history and goes through a list of symptoms to check if the patient has experienced any. The patient reports that they have not experienced any of the symptoms.

The 56 year old right-handed patient reports experiencing lower back pain on and off since a motor vehicle accident in September 2005. The pain started five days after the accident and has traveled from their right lower back to their buttocks, posterior thigh, and outside of calf. Sitting for long periods exacerbates the pain and relief is found when standing or laying down. Walking makes it slightly less painful. They have not experienced weakness or pain in either leg, nor changes in bowel movements or urine function. Painkillers and an injection in the back did not provide significant relief. Straight leg raising test was normal.
Patient is married and works part-time as a farmer. Denies tobacco, alcohol, or drug use.

The doctor asks the patient if she has had any surgeries, and clarifies that it includes anything like joint replacement or C-section. The patient has never had surgery and had all her children naturally.
Patient confirms taking Morphine, Darvocet, Flomax, Avodart, and Ibuprofen as listed in the updated medical chart.
GENERAL APPEARANCE: Well developed and well nourished without any acute distress.
The patient does not have any knowledge of any health problems in their family history.

The patient is experiencing pain on the upper right side of the chest and nausea, and has a reduced appetite. The doctor reviews the patient's medical history and asks about other symptoms and family history.

The patient, a 68-year-old female has been experiencing knee pain for 13 years and previously underwent a knee replacement. She is now experiencing pain, snapping, giving away sensation, and trouble walking. She had an x-ray that showed malalignment of the hardware from the previous surgery. She expressed interest in another surgery.

This is an appointment between a doctor and a patient accompanied by his daughter. The patient reports that he has been doing well and denies any symptoms of heart disease, failure, or falls. His blood sugar has been normal and he has no incontinence or memory issues. However, he mentions that his right knee is causing him pain occasionally and asks if a knee brace would be helpful. He manages the pain with Tylenol as needed.
The doctor informs the patient that the male breast tissue is normal and nothing to be concerned about. The patient acknowledges and accepts this information.
Patient started protein-rich diet with whey protein and greens. Doctor complimented patient on appearance and encouraged to continue the diet.

URINARY: Patient has a history of frequent UTIs, but currently no symptoms. Patient is drinking more water and taking preventative measures. No fever or chills. Weight is stable. RESPIRATORY: No coughing, congestion, chest pain, or shortness of breath. GASTROINTESTINAL: No bleeding in feces or rectum, no constipation, stomach pain, nausea, or vomiting as of late.

The doctor inquires about the patient's medical history. The patient mentions having prostate cancer and difficulty with urinary incontinence. The patient also reveals having a hip replacement surgery on the left side.
Patient not restrained but has palm protector in right hand.

The patient smokes cigarettes, but doesn't drink or use recreational drugs. He lives with his wife and is currently unemployed, but was previously employed as an IT software developer. The doctor expresses sympathy for his situation.
The patient has many relatives who suffer from high blood pressure and diabetes.
MEDICAL: Patient has mild soreness in left arm due to the vaccine; R O S is normal.
The patient has improved after taking Prednisone for redness and swelling. The doctor asks if this was the patient's first wasp sting, and the patient confirms it was and hopes it will be the last.
The patient does not recall having any surgeries.
The patient does not have any history of psychiatric disorders or mood disorders.

The patient's mother and sister are present in the conversation as family members. They suspect that the patient has used drugs, but don't know which ones. The doctor suspects some drug use as well and encourages them to reach out with any questions.

The doctor asks the patient about GI issues before asking about other general health issues, such as heart, genital or urinary tract issues and range of motion. The patient does not report any issues in these areas.

The doctor collects background information about the patient's employment, lifestyle, relationship status, activity level, and last drug test. The patient is on disability, does not drink or smoke, lives with his girlfriend, has minimal activity level, and cannot recall his last drug test.

In this conversation, the doctor questions the patient about any past hospitalizations. The patient mentions a skateboarding accident that nearly hospitalized him two years ago. They go on to discuss the patient's history with skateboarding and where they typically skateboard. The doctor expresses admiration for those who have skills in skateboarding.

A 75-year-old woman is feeling weak and shaky. She cannot breathe properly when walking and it's getting harder for her to move around. She doesn't have any chest pain, palpitations, cough, bloody sputum, wheezing, or fainting spells. She has been feeling like this for a while but it's getting worse lately.

The doctor asked the patient how they were feeling after they complained of a headache. The patient said they get migraines occasionally and that weather changes make them worse. The doctor suggested they see a neurologist and offered to write a referral. The patient agreed to make an appointment.
GENERAL HEALTH: No chest pain, shortness of breath or bleeding disorders. Gastrointestinal and urinary tract reports available. No additional concerns.
Patient had a femur fracture repaired on the right side, specifically the intertrochanteric femur.

The patient is an 85-year-old with a complaint of muscle pain in the right buttocks region that is suspected to be radiating from the lower back. No other symptoms are reported except for a history of high blood pressure which is better managed and relieved using medication. The patient reports trying Tylenol with slight relief, and the doctor prescribes a stronger medication and plans for x-rays if the pain persists.
No known drug allergies.

The doctor asks about the patient's weekend and finds out she went to a party and now has back pain. The doctor asks if she drank alcohol and the patient says yes, but only on special occasions so she drinks occasionally.
The patient has high blood pressure and borderline elevated cholesterol levels. The doctor wants to monitor the cholesterol levels by having the patient come back in a month for another check-up.
No symptoms reported.

The guest family is at the hospital with their two-month-old child who has been sick for the past week with congestion, a cough, irregular breathing, a fever ranging between 102 and 104 degrees, and decreased feeding and urination. The family's son also has an upper respiratory infection. The child has been spitting up and throwing up after coughing, and is experiencing similar symptoms after feeding. However, the child has not had any diarrhea. The doctor expresses sympathy for the family and promises to help.
The patient is taking multivitamins and calcium supplements as medication.
Patient with a boil on their buttock. Doctor acknowledging it.

The patient is experiencing a weird sensation of facial twitching and grimacing, along with occasional pins and needles pressure in the head which feels like water is running down the hair. They are taking Aleve for pain relief. The patient is also suffering from daytime sleepiness, difficulty falling asleep at night, and only getting around five hours of sleep per night due to working from 4 PM to midnight. The quality of sleep is good, but they wake up to use the bathroom. The patient denies difficulty catching their breath or sleep apnea.
The patient had surgeries on their foot, knee, and tummy.

The patient has come for a routine physical checkup and reports that there are no changes in their social history or medical conditions. The doctor agrees that prevention is important and reviews the chart to confirm the patient's information.
The patient doesn't have any known drug allergies.
The patient has a lump in the left side of their chest, which has grown over the past year, causing tenderness and pain when taking deep breaths. The patient is a 56-year-old white man.

The guest's family reports that she has been experiencing ear pain and blowing up green snot for about six days in both ears. The doctor checks her and finds fluid buildup in her right middle ear and diagnoses her with sinusitis. Prescribes antibiotics and wants her to come back for follow up to ensure the fluid is gone.
No known allergies reported.

The doctor is speaking with a family whose 2.5-year-old daughter has a history of seizures and is currently taking Keppra for it. The family noticed that the child has been staring blankly and not responding for around 10-15 seconds. On one occasion, her mouth turned blue. The mother thinks it lasts for three to four minutes, while one episode seemed to last around thirty to forty seconds. The doctor notes that the child's dosage of Keppra is lower than expected and may need to be increased.
The doctor asks the patient if there are any medical conditions that run in their family. The patient mentions that their grandfather had a history of alcoholism.
Patient taking anxiety medication and estrogen.
Patient is allergic to Sulfa drugs and experiences dizziness and vomiting when taking them.
Patient is the only one in the family suffering from heart problems.
The patient comes for a checkup and reports experiencing joint pain for a few weeks, hoping to get help with diagnosis and treatment.
Patient takes Excedrin or ibuprofen for headaches but they don't work. No history of prescription medication for headaches.
First pregnancy, patient excited for baby's arrival.
Patient denies smoking and drinking alcohol.
Patient has three healthy children that live with her and her boyfriend. Patient does not use drugs or tobacco, and drinks only on rare occasions.

The patient has been experiencing numbness and tingling in their right hand for the past few weeks, with the symptoms being worse at night. The patient has a desk job where they use a computer and keyboard for eight hours a day, with no recent major changes to their daily routine. The symptoms mostly occur in the middle finger but also affect other fingers and occasionally cause pain in the thumb. The patient wonders if it might be carpal tunnel or arthritis, but the doctor suggests getting a test to confirm any diagnosis.
Patient stopped taking Prevacid due to diarrhea.

The doctor is discussing the patient's recent medical procedures with the patient's family. The family explains that the P bag was recently changed and there is no urine in it because they did a straight catheterization and took the urine out for lab analysis. The doctor confirms that there were no leukocytes seen, indicating no infection, but there was blood during catheterization. The x-ray revealed stool in the colon but the doctor assures them that the patient is fine and active.
The patient reports no medical history or family medical issues and does not drink or smoke.
Patient in stable condition, unable to provide medical history. Guest clinician to be paged when patient is awake and can answer questions.

The patient has been diagnosed with serotonin syndrome based on the elevated white count and C P K count found in her labs. She is experiencing symptoms such as agitation and diarrhea. The doctor suggests giving her IV fluids and discontinuing Prozac. After treatment, her C P K and white blood cell counts have become almost normal. The patient also talks about her depression, anxiety, and panic attacks, and how her psychiatrist recommended taking Cymbalta instead of Prozac. Finally, she mentions that she has a friend who will help her go home after her stay is over, and the doctor advises her to continue taking medication for high blood pressure and diabetes.

The patient has a history of epilepsy and non-epileptic issues. She is concerned that she is having seizures again because of strange body aches and confusion upon waking up in the mornings, and also while she is at work. She lives alone and does not have anyone to confirm whether she is having seizures or not. The doctor suggests performing a video EEG to gather more information on whether the events are epileptic seizures or something else. The patient agrees to this and is available to schedule the video EEG on the same day. The nurse will be called in to set up the procedure.

A nasogastric tube was inserted for decompression and the doctor asked the patient how they are feeling. The patient responded hesitantly and the family said that the patient mentioned feeling better.

The patient has metastatic prostate cancer which has spread to the bladder and various parts of the body. He has noticed blood in his urine again and has chronic lower back pain, but no incontinence, fever, belly pain, nausea, or vomiting. The patient has completed chemotherapy and is currently receiving radiation therapy targeted at the bones for pain relief. The doctor asks about hospice care and the patient expresses interest. The focus of treatment is currently on comfort.

Patient complains of pain on the right side under the ribs during a follow-up. The doctor reviews the patient's medical history, which includes hives, dialysis for two years and high blood pressure. The doctor suspects a possible association between the patient's kidney problems and high blood pressure. Further examination is required.
The doctor found a foreign object in the patient's left eye, and the family is asking if the patient needs to see an eye doctor after this.

The doctor believes that the patient is having a febrile seizure due to his high fever. A guest clinician agrees with the doctor's assessment. The patient's family is concerned and the doctor will examine the patient.
Patient drinks occasionally wine with dinner, but no use of tobacco or drugs.
The patient denies any history of alcohol, drug abuse and smoking.
Patient has already provided medication information to the nurse; confirmed with doctor that they are not on blood thinners.

The doctor asks the patient's age and race before inquiring about how he was injured. The patient injured his left leg after stepping off a hilo at work and felt a pop in the back of his leg. He has been placed in a splint and referred to ABC orthopedics for follow-up.

A family member brings their son's school reports to a doctor for evaluation. The son is struggling in school, asks a lot of questions, is obsessed with cleaning, and has trouble relating to classmates. He has also been collecting old toys and has shown signs of confusion and depression. He will be attending a social skills program over the summer and has been referred to two psychologists for functional behavioral analysis. The doctor discusses his medication and notes that stopping Zoloft has improved his tremors.

The patient recently had a follow-up with their cardiologist after undergoing bypass surgery. The doctor checked the patient's EKG, which was normal. The patient is the only one in their family with heart disease.
Patient is not on any medication, and the doctor is updating the electronic health record (EHR).

A mother brings her daughter to a dermatology office because of skin issues. They just came from Tanzania, and their ethnicity is black. The daughter has a history of atopic eczema and has been using Elidel cream twice a day for six months, which is no longer effective. They are now using Johnson's Baby oil. The doctor will see what else can help the daughter's rashes.
No known allergies.

The patient accidentally jabbed themselves with a needle while working with a patient. The patient they were working with tested positive for Hepatitis C, but is only a carrier and will not show symptoms. The patient is scared and has come for regular screening. The doctor checks the patient's medical history and sees that they have received Hepatitis B shots and their antibodies are showing. Liver function tests were normal in February 2005 and the patient has no local signs of infection, except for intestinal issues. The doctor examines the patient's abdomen and finds it to be fine with no fever or swelling.
The doctor asked the patient how they were feeling and the patient responded by saying they were weak and shaky. The doctor apologized and the patient reassured them that it was okay.
Patient wants cancer treatment, family history positive for cancer.
The patient lives with her husband and her daughter and son-in-law check on them every day.  She denies using ethanol, tobacco, or illicit substances.
The patient's family history includes breast and bone cancer as well as diabetes on both sides of the family. The doctor expresses sympathy for the patient's family's medical issues.

The doctor is speaking to a young patient and his mother about the boy's previous arm injury, a recent rebreak, and the need to remove a nail. The doctor explains the procedure and says the risk of infection is low. The boy will be asleep during the surgery.

The patient takes Aspirin, blood pressure medicine, and diabetes medicine. The labels on the medication bottles are in Spanish. The doctor reviews the medication bottles provided by the patient's family.
The guest family has brought their two-week-old son to the doctor's office to ask a question about his foreskin, but otherwise the baby is doing well with no other problems reported.
Patient has a family history of stroke, heart issues, and high blood pressure. Used to be a heavy smoker (2-3 packs per day) before quitting in 1990. Worked as a feed salesman throughout adulthood.

The doctor is talking to a family whose eighteen-month-old baby has had a fever for five days that is higher at night. The baby has finished taking medication for a sinus infection and takes Zyrtec for allergies. The doctor asks if the fever fluctuates and if there are any other symptoms such as vomiting or diarrhea, but the family says there are none of these symptoms. The doctor discovers that the baby's tooth is coming out and this could explain the fussiness and drooling. The family reports that the baby eats well and doesn't have a cough, though they do see discolored mucus in the morning.
Back surgery for disc issue. No known other surgeries.
The patient has FCR tendinitis and has received cortisone shots in the past. The doctor asks about hobbies and the possible impact on the pain. The patient asks for the doctor's opinion on surgery.
The patient's father had diabetes and has passed away. The doctor expressed condolences.
The patient is experiencing chronic pain all over their body due to previous injuries. They have a history of heroin use, which they have resumed to cope with the pain when it becomes severe.

The patient is a white, 47-year-old female who is concerned about a spider bite on the back of her left shoulder. She noticed it two days ago and it has become tender and red. She also has red streaks going up her neck. The doctor asks about the tenderness of the bite and if the patient has a fever, but she has not.
Patient denies any history of surgeries, including gallbladder or appendix removal and joint replacements.

The patient lives with their family, consisting of their parents and two younger sisters. They enjoy spending time together and have weekly game nights and often go on hikes on weekends. Patient has not been in contact with any sick individuals.
The doctor reviewed the patient's shoulder x-ray and found it to be normal with no bone abnormalities or wear and tear.

The patient is a 51-year-old male with degenerative joint disease in his big toe, causing him pain that has been getting progressively worse. The doctor offers surgical options which the patient agrees to pursue.
The patient was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease by a doctor named Johnson five years ago.
Patient had tonsillectomy due to frequent infections.

1. Patient is concerned about her wrinkles and wants to look younger at the age of 57. 2. Doctor asks about smoking and skin diseases. 3. Doctor examines the patient's face and identifies full submandibular and mid-face regions and prominent nasolabial folds.

A new patient, a 38-year-old woman, is experiencing pain in her hips for the past two years, with the right side being more painful than the left. The pain is increasing and is located in the front and on the side. Walking causes pain and the patient hears popping and clicking in her hip. She has not seen another doctor before.

The patient is 53 years old and has a herniated disc at T8-T9 causing rib pain. The patient has tried anti-inflammatories and rest to manage the pain with no success. They ask the doctor if surgery is an option.
The doctor asks if the patient has any chronic diseases, and gives examples such as high blood pressure, diabetes, depression, and arthritis. The patient admits to having high blood pressure.

A 58-year-old female suddenly became blind with complaints of tongue numbness and slurred speech. Her vision improved slightly on her way to the local emergency room, but worsened on arrival. She became unresponsive and was transferred to U I H C where her symptoms improved upon arrival. These were the first time she had experienced any of these symptoms.
The patient's immediate family has no history of depression, but a second cousin has had depression and a nervous breakdown.

The patient had taken Macrobid for E coli, but had a skin rash and hives and stopped the medication. Painful urination, blood in urine, fever, and chills were all absent. The patient urinates every two to three hours and controlling urine well. Pelvic exercises were helpful in rehabilitation. The renal ultrasound in August 2008 showed no kidney issues. The patient had E coli a few times in late 2007 and early 2008.
The patient takes P M for sleeplessness, water pill, blood thinner, multivitamins, and folic. They also take Norvasc, Lanoxin, Diovan, and Atenolol medications for their blood pressure.

This is a follow-up appointment for a 37-year-old left-handed male who presented with headaches, nausea, and vomiting one month ago. He has been experiencing blurred vision, difficulty concentrating, and worsening headaches upon sitting up in the morning. His headaches are dull and constant, with a sensation of pressure around his head. He experiences nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to bright light and loud sounds. His weight has fluctuated over the past three months, and he has lost his appetite. His neurological exam reveals no blind spots, numbness, tingling, double vision, or speech difficulties.

The patient is married and lives in a single-level home without stairs. She and her husband are both doing well, and she does not smoke but occasionally drinks alcohol. She used to exercise daily but stopped due to back pain in 2008. She currently works full time as a project manager and walks extensively during the day.
The patient enjoys traveling and has been to more than six countries, but hasn't traveled abroad recently.

RESPIRATORY: Shortness of breath after exertion. 
URINARY/BOWEL: No reported issues. 
HEMATOLOGIC: No excessive or unstoppable bleeding issues.

The patient's mother died of stomach cancer, their sister had Alzheimer's disease, their father died in a car accident, and their brother died from mesothelioma caused by asbestos exposure while working in the shipyards.
The patient is allergic to Cephalexin, but does not have any other known medication allergies.
The patient had a history of smoking but has quit, and does not consume alcohol.

The patient, who has had a stroke, is accompanied by her power of attorney for a doctor's visit. She experiences a constant urge to urinate and has occasional urination accidents. Multiple medications have been tried with no success and no voiding diary has been kept. There is no pain or blood in the urine or any other issues except the need for Depends. A review of previous urodynamics implies significant detrusor instability with involuntary urinary incontinence and low bladder volumes although cystoscopy was normal.
The patient has asthma.

The patient had their 41st birthday and identifies as white. They were previously treated for HIV and their CD4 count was 425 and viral load was less than 50 in August of 2007.
